STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 4, 2025
Stephanie Rae Sears
Methodist Children’s Home Society
26645 W 6 Mile Rd.
Detroit, MI, 48240-2319
RE: License#: CB820201295
Dear Ms. Sears:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 1/12/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201295
Licensee Group Organization: Methodist Children's Home Society
Licensee Designee: Kevin M Roach
Chief Administrator: Stephanie Rae Sears
Name of Agency: Methodist Children's Home Society
Agency Address: 26645 W 6 Mile Rd
Detroit, MI 48240-2319
Agency Telephone #: 3135314060
Original Issuance Date: 10/24/1994
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 1/6/25; 1/7/25; offsite 1/10/25; 1/12/25
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 42 6
Homes pending licensure 3 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 8 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 10 3
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 4 4
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management
(placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 137 8
Children discharged from care during this period 34 6
Youth in independent living placement 18 3
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 8 3
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection 9 4
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection 0 0
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection 9 4
Open child adoption cases 41 6
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 14 5
Less than a year 11 11
Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 3
Adoption Staff 1
Supervisory Staff 1
Administrative Staff 2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 39 3
Unlicensed relative homes 54 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 5
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
The agency requires annual ICHAT for its employees:
Two of five employee records reviewed where the employee had been employed
for over one year showed the employee’s annual ICHAT due by 3/23/2024 and
10/11/2024 respectively was not documented at the time of the record review.
The agency completed the respective ICHAT later that day on 1/7/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One of 11 new employee records reviewed did not show three references as
required by the rule.

CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a
written evaluation of the convictions that addresses the
nature of the conviction, the length of time since the
conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to
regulated activity.
One of 11 new employee records reviewed showed the employee had a 2009
conviction; and a written evaluation by the chief administrator or his or her
designee related the conviction was not documented.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(g) A written statement from the employee regarding
any convictions.
One of 11 new employee records reviewed showed the employee had a 2009
conviction; and a written statement from the employee was not documented, with
respect to the employee’s position.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
Two of 11 new employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the employee had resided in the state of Arizona and
Maine in the last five years preceding the employee’s 9/9/2024 date of
hire and the record did not show documentation of a child abuse
clearance from those states.

• A second record showed the employee had resided in the state of Florida
in the last five years preceding the employee’s 11/18/2024 date of hire
and the record did not show documentation of a child abuse clearance
from Florida.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Five of 16 employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the employee’s probationary evaluation due by
7/1/2024 was completed late on 9/12/2024.
• A second record showed the employee’s probationary evaluation due by
5/20/2024 was completed late on 9/6/2024.
• A third, fourth, and fifth record showed the respective employee’s annual
evaluation due by 3/28/2024, 3/22/2024 and 3/21/2024 was completed late
on 4/10/2024, 4/4/2024 and 4/5/2024 respectively.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/21/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household must
have training in and maintain a current certification in
first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the
American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross, or other institution approved by the department.
One of six open foster home records reviewed showed the foster parent’s
CPR/First Aid certification due by 9/12/2024 was completed late on 9/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a
determination and assessment of all the following:

(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with,
each member of the household and each social service
worker who has had children placed in the home during
the last licensing period.
One of six open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation of a
summary of the interview with the foster parent. Nor documentation of the foster
parent’s individual strengths and weaknesses as reported by the foster parent, as
r equired by the rule and the reevaluation document.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
One of six open foster home records reviewed showed the agency’s
recommendation to the department was not submitted at least 15 days of the
foster home’s 4/30/2024 licensing expiration date.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
One of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(a). The information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/21/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.

One of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(b). The information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/21/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's dental exam
due by 11/17/2024 was completed late on 11/25/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations must begin
within 30 calendar days of placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s
DTP/DTaP/DT/Td/Tdap immunization and Hepatitis A immunization was overdue
by 9/24/2023, 2/27/2024 respectively and neither had been brought current.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's 8/16/2024-
11/16/2024 updated service plan (USP) was completed two days late.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP Approved 1/31/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child’s 5/21/2024-8/15/2024 treatment plan was
not signed by the caegiver. Addtionally the child’s record showed two
treatment plans related to the caregiver and birth parent with written
statements on them that the plan was either mailed or the person refused
to sign it. In regards to those treatment plans I could not discern whether
the action indicated was completed timely with respect to the signature
requirement time frames. Neither document was dated .
• A second record showed the child’s 9/7/2024-12/1/2024 treatment plan
was not signed by the caregiver or birth parent.
• A third record showed the child’s 4/24/2024-5/24/2024 treatment plan, and
5/25/2024-8/14/2024 treatment plan was not signed by the caregiver. The
child’s 5/25/2024- 8/14/2024 treatment plan for the birth parent indicated it
was mailed to the birth parent. This latter treatment plan was not dated;
and I could not discern if it was mailed timely with respect to the signature
requirement timeframe.
• A fourth record showed the child’s 7/18/24-8/15/2024 treatment plan was
signed by caregiver but not dated. I could not discern if this treatment plan
was signed timely, per the signature requirement timeframe.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/21/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s initial service
plan did not show documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP Approved 3/21/2024.
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 1/31/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be
documented in the youth's record.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of a medical or dental for the youth, due by 8/7/2024 and
9/6/2024 respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for
the child or children, visitation/parenting time with the
youth's biological children or a clear explanation why
this is not possible or appropriate.

Three of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record showed the youth’s 7/1/24-7/31/24 ISP was not approved by
the supervisor until 1/1/2025; and thereon the youth’s 8/1/2024-
10/29/2024 USP was completed 68 days late on 1/6/2025.
• A second youth’s 6/18/24-9/15/24 USP was completed 87 days late on
12/12/2024.
• A third youth’s 1/5/2024-4/3/2024 USP was completed 20 days late on
4/24/2044. This youth’s 9/24/24-12/16/24 USP was completed 4 days late
on 12/27/2024. This youth’s 1/5/2024- 4/3/2024 treatment plan was signed
by the youth but not dated and I could not discern whether this treatment
plan was signed timely.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024; CAP approved 3/21/2024.
Renewal, CAP approved 1/31/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for
prospective applicants for adoption before an adoptive
application is provided.
One of three adoptive applicant records reviewed showed the applicant was
provided an application prior to an orientation.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
One of three adoptive applicant records reviewed showed the family’s adoptive
evaluation was not completed within 90 days of the family’s 11/27/2023
application date.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.

One of three adoptive applicant records reviewed showed the family’s
10/10/2024 and 10/16/2024 evaluations were not provided to the family until
12/2/2024.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 1/31/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless greter frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into
an out-of placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s medical was
due on 8/17/2024 and the agency showed verification of a medical for the child on
9/25/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP Approved 3/21/2024.
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 1/31/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-evaluatio examination must be obtained
at least every 9 months, unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child who entered
care with the agency on 10/8/2023 had not had a dental exam since 1/27/2022
and proof of one was not uploaded. The agency showed verfication a dental
occurred for the child on 6/20/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 1/31/2023.

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from
the medical or dental provider for all medical and dental
care received by a foster care
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show uploaded
documentation of the actual medical or dental report for the child from the medical
or dental provider. The agency showed proof of the child’s medical or dental by
way of care-connect.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12502(2) Program statement & R400.12503(3) Policies & procedures.
• The agency was apprised it shall clearly and consistently show that the youth
received documentation related to these rules before or by the youth’s date of
placement.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12417 Foster parent information.
• The agency was given consultation related to the form tool it utilizes to ensure
information required by this rule is obtained.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period:
• The first incident related to an allegation that the foster mother “whupped” the
foster children with her hand on their bottom and back. During the special
evaluation the two older of the children and the foster parent’s daughter
confirmed the foster mother spanked the children. The foster parent was
found in noncompliance with of the behavior management rule and household
maintenance rule with respect to allegations of a cluttered home. A corrective

action plan was completed with the foster parent around both violations,
which include that the foster parent was to complete trauma informed
behavior management training. The agency appeared to have acted
appropriately related to this matter and it adhered to departmental timeframes
and requirements related to the special evaluation.
• The second incident related to an allegation that the foster mother spanked
her four-year-old grandson (who was visiting her from his relative foster
home) with a shoe on his butt, because he urinated on himself. The agency’s
special evaluation found the foster parent in violation of the behavior
management rule, after the foster parent and child confirmed physical
discipline was used by the foster parent. A corrective action plan was
completed with foster parent around proper forms of discipline. The agency
adhered to departmental standards related to the special evaluation.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period:
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 Interim inspection
where it received 18 rule violations.
During this current inspection for the agency’s renewal license, the agency received
24 rule violations. This was an increase from the last inspection. Of these 24
citations, 10 are repeat violations within the last two years (6 are specific repeats
violation from the last inspection). The agency’s CAP compliance around these 6
rule violations is as follows: the number of individual cases cited remained the same
with respect to 5 of the rule violations cited; and the number of individual cases
cited with respect to the other rule increased by 2.
Supervision case notes, training documentation, file reviews; and worker interviews
provided proof of the agency implementing and working on its CAP. Various action
steps were completed and or implemented, but the agency was not totally
successful with all aspects of the CAP; as shown by the repeat violations.
Notwithstanding the repeat citations, per this inspective review it showed the
agency had positive gains; various training/discussions were completed for
employees on the CAP, and there were no missed caregiver/foster parent home
visits, or sibling visits.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2024SIC0001442, related to a complaint received on 5/17/2024. It was alleged the
agency failed to report injuries on a child for two weeks. The special investigation
found the agency in violation of rule R400.12214 Compliance to the child protection
law. An acceptable corrective action plan was submitted, that indicated the staff

would be trained on the child protection law; compliance would be monitored during
child welfare meetings; and training would occur with new staff during onboarding.
The corrective action plan was approved on 7/26/2024. The agency has
implemented this corrective action plan, and they are in compliance with it.
The third corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2024SIC0001680,
related to a complaint received on 8/13/2024. It was alleged youths in Independent
Living are confined to their rooms, cannot get out once the door is closed, no fire
extinguishers, there is limited staff, and the windows do not open. The special
investigation found that the windows were not able to be open in the event of an
emergency. The agency submitted an acceptable correct plan which was approved
on 11/15/2024. The corrective action plan indicated the agency would obtain
quotes from vendors and select a vendor for new window installations. The agency
has made progress related to quotes, and window purchasing. The windows’
delivery was expected later in the week of 1/6/2025, with the windows anticipated to
be installed within the next month.
The agency has implemented this corrective action plan and are executing it.
The agency has three other special investigations where actions are pending:
Special investigation 2025SIC000065 related to a complaint received on
10/29/2024, that included an allegation that the youth was supposed to have
staples removed from their head within five days and staff did not comply with this
even though they were aware of the recommendation. Additional allegations were
that a youth was prescribed medication for various diagnoses and there had been
multiple occasions where his medication was delayed by a day or more.
The agency was found in violation of R400.12507 for Medical, dental and mental
health care after the special investigation determined the agency failed to follow-up
to have the youth’s staples removed as the doctor recommended. It was also
revealed the agency was locking up the youth’s medication, had taken charge of
storage/administration of the youth’s medication; and the youth had missed some of
his medication due to two of his medications running out.
Additionally, the agency was found in violation of R400.12504(1) for Eligibility
requirements; which centered on a lack of appropriate documentation of the youths’
rationale for independent living placement in the program; and R400.12509(3)(o)
Independent living record due to the special investigation revealing there were late
service plans.
The special investigation report was recently provided to the agency. An acceptable
corrective action plan from the agency is pending.

Special investigation 2025SIC000103 related to a complaint received on
11/12/2024. It is alleged a youth who is autistic went AWOL on 10/23/2024 and the
agency did not follow proper notification procedures until 10/25/2024. This special
investigating completion is pending.
Special investigation 2025SIC0000261 related to a complaint received on 1/6/2025.
It is alleged there was a physical altercation between a staff and youth where the
staff allegedly swung on the youth and placed the youth in a choke hold. The
completion of this special investigation is pending.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s report dated 1/8/2025. The chief
administrator reported staff retention and turnover continued to be a challenge in
2024, and many workers left the agency due to pursuing other social work
opportunities outside of the child welfare field or left for more competitive salaries
or work/life balances. Other challenges identified related to changes in supervisors
and case workers struggling with timely data entries, MISACWIS uploads and
report submission. Likewise, the chief administrator’s report indicated the agency
continued to experience some difficulties complying with rules R400.12405;
R400.12413; R40012419 and R400.12509. The chief administrator reported not
withstanding those struggles they continue to work to improve in those areas. She
reported they have seen an increase in compliance with their contract related to
adoption, foster care, borrowed bed paper work and overall independent living
documentation. She also reported meeting and trainings with staff have been
helpful; and that they review social work contacts and the Book of Business
weekly during supervision with workers and supervisors.
The agency plans to continue their efforts to increase compliances overall and are
hopeful related to staff retention.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual budget for 2025; and an independent financial
audit for the year end 12/31/2023. A review of these documents did not reveal an
area of concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, the director of foster care
services at the entrance conference, and both of these staff along with three
supervisors at the exit conference, two foster care workers, a licensing worker and
a foster care/adoption worker were interviewed. Areas of strengths for the agency
as reported by the staff included there being strong teams, positive communication
and involvement across programs, and the director and supervisors being diligent
about having meetings to keep staff involved and informed. Area of growth needed
included improved communication about changes the come up, with clarity being

offered; and greater organization around getting staff into systems that affects how
they do their work and get paid.
Description of Agency Walk Through
No safety issue or concerns were revealed during my site visit. The agency has
space and equipment for its staff and stores files securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts this reporting period.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
January 16, 2025
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 4, 2025
_____________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Program Manager
